comments.commentBody:
What nonsense, wrapped in sentimentality. A NYT "Pick" at that!

Expression of strong sentiments here -- overwhelmingly for gun control and against violence and bigotry -- is not related in any way to "these killings." The shooters in these tragedies have nothing in common with the sentiments expressed by the majority of commentators to the NYT. You actually accuse most of the commentators to this article of "hatred"?!

If your Silent Majority (where have we heard that before?), some sort of mushy middle (neither for nor against gun control, perhaps?) actually exists, go and organize it. I think that you are just trying to derail a serious discussion of a serious problem.

"People often spoke of being sucked into a “reality distortion field” as he pitched his new products. "

This is NOT the original definition of Steve's RDF, but the one co-opted by others. Steve didn't pitch anything to the masses, the product announcements were to the jaded media. Calling something "magical" does not put Steve in the "mold of a magician".

"The way the audience oohed and aahed during his performance was as if Mr. Jobs was saying: “Step right up! Ladies and gentlemen. Boys and girls of all ages! See the latest magical Apple device. You can stretch your fingers on the flat screen and zoom into a photo or map!”"

Yeah, that audience was composed primarily of tech journalists. Perhaps, you should tell your fellow tech journos to act their age and be more cynical and curmudgeonly. Acting human and expressing wonder, is embarrassing to serious journos.

"It’s also one reason Apple is so annoyingly tight-lipped."

Yeah, Apple makes a tech journos' job so "annoyingly" hard. Nick, let your true feelings out! You're a tech journalist. No need for dispassionate analysis, let your personal distaste show.

You have forgotten your Roman History. How do you think the emperors ruled the Capitolso efficiently? They hired a special "police force" and ensured that these men got special treatment and high pay. As a result the "Praetorian guard" as it was called, only had allegiance to the emperor, not to the state.
Today's police already feel apart and alienated from most of American society and as a result as long as they are paid well, they will perform the unpleasant duties of an occupying military power.

Instead of critiquing this article which I planned to do, I am going to offer my solution to Oakland's problems.  Operation Ceasefire needs to be implemented fully in Oakland, and the overpaid cops and firefighters need to take a 10% pay cut. I recognize these are incredibly hard jobs but police and fire are 2/3 of the city's budget, and police get paid the highest starting salary in California. With this extra money the city can divide it in half: half to new police officers, and half to social services to combat Oakland's crime rate. These programs could include job programs that lower recidivism rates, increasing library hours, and cleaning up parks. Also Oakland needs to accept that economic growth is GOOD for the city, and that gentrification has its perks. Also Oakland needs some decent leadership, and that includes getting a new mayor after Quan's term is up. Oakland needs a strong leader at the top who deeply cares about the city like Quan, but doesn't have the flip-floppiness of Mitt Romney. Also Oakland needs the Occupy Movement to work with the city and its residents. Otherwise, Occupy Oakland will be known as a group of mostly-out-of-towners commited to wrecking Oakland and everything that good in it. Finally, Oakland is a great city and that is why almost 400,000 people call it home. For Oakland to prosper we need to rally around our city and commit to make it better every day.
English takes in words from other languages very easily.  That's an admirable strength, in my opinion.
'The most anticipated event in London Olympics' said enough. Usain Bolt owns the 17 days, not anyone else regardless more many medals were handed out.

Thanks NYT. Sunday night. Stayed up as late as I could to watch this most important event of the Olympics. Could wait no longer. Read it in the Times.
Goodnight NBC. Stronger people than me will have to suffer through your insane decision to put this at the end of the evening in order to maximize your ad revenues.

We're not all gringos. Nor are we Anglos. In the US, we do call ourselves Americans. As does much of the world.  If you live in one of the Americas feel free to call yourself an American, too. Don't be so sensitive.
Actually, "America" is two continents.  Please henceforth specify "North" or "South" when referencing.  Thank you for your co-operation.

I am currently trying to UNteach this to my 5 year old, who learned to call the US America from a teacher at school.  As someone who has spent a lot of time in Latin America, this drives me NUTS and I am totally infuriated that a teacher taught this ignorance to my son.  You are correct that we are all Americans.

Have you noticed that America has not won a single medal ?
Why ?
Because America is not a country but a continent ! The United States of America has won the medals. It is not the fault of the rest of Americans that you can´t find a name for yourselves, ergo, gringos.

Nonsense ! Jamaican's have had a long an lunimous Olympic track and field tradition starting in 1948 with Herb Mc,Kinley, Arthur Wint, Donald Quarrie, Merlene Ottey and others. Further they have a 100+ year tradition of inter school athletic competition called "Champs" which annually involves every "middle" and high school. From those participants and even younger the best are culled and groomed to be among the Olympians we see today. I presume for some in the "first world" and other naysayers it may require a leap of faith just to to wrap their heads around the fact that a tiny developing nation with a population less that of Brooklyn, NY and with much less resources at their disposal than most nations; seems to have little or .... "no problem man" consistently producing the World Champion sprinters that countries like my beloved USA have had a scandalous history in their attempts to produce same. Do some research (see Canadian, British and even Jamaican media reports) on how the frequency of testing of the Jamaican team at the Beijing Olympics came up with...NOTHING! Sorry, this belated and oft repeated but never substantiated allegation of "juicing" seems to me like well...."sour grapes". Bolt is 25, perhaps close to his peak but certainly not in decline. Like Phelps, he's may just. be extraordinary or gifted and yes, physically and mentally superior, a true competitor just like other Olympians, past and present. PEACE....ONE LOVE!
Sour grapes, or prejudice?
So I imagine you think Phelps, Lebron or Kobi is on dope?  These people make it to the Olympics becasue they are exceptionally talented and work hard to boot.  Period.

Ufnortunately, I Bolt's performance, and that of the other Jamacians, appears too good to be true. In years to come, he'll be in the same position Lance Armstrong now is. And track, las well as bicycle racing, will be over.
The BOLT from The Blue Gods !!

Carl Lewis took cold medicine shortly after it was banned. It was deemed to be an unintentional violation of the rules. Johnson took steroids and admitted taking it for most of his career. Those are not the same situation at all.
The women's record is 10.49 seconds.
Actually, the world's fastest HUMAN.
Carl Lewis was like that, too -- a "big event" guy.

The Republicans have nearly given up having a "side" of an issue.  They have little but empty, infinitely repeated, emotionalized propaganda.  A newspaper that repeats Republican lies without noting that they are lies is not a "news"paper.
To say nothing of Hispanic and African....

Wisconsin?
The electorate can't be naive enough to vote for Romney.

I think you'll find the English colonists fought the French and their native American allies in cementing the English colonial presence in North America during the first half of the 18th century, and paying for that war was, ironically, a central issue leading to the American Revolution. Our culture, and economic and legal traditions, are mostly rooted in Britain, including basic rights like trial by jury, a privilege that never existed in much of Continental Europe. Our capitalist system, so basic to our identity and way of life, grew out of classical economics developed in Britain, with which France has never been entirely comfortable, remaining an agrarian society long after the Industrial Revolution transformed Britain and America, and never even developed a modern banking system until well into the 19th century.
France is a friendly nation with many attributes, but its role in the development of America should not be overstated.

Of course, these laws were not written to discriminate against minorities. The laws are obviously written to separate those who have so many cars that the need a car elevator in on of their vacation homes from those people who are so poor that they see no possibility that they will ever own a car and thus need a driver's license.

To put the non-discriminatory intent and effect of these laws, we need only remember Anatole France's explanation:

"The law, in its majestic equality, forbids the rich as well as the poor to sleep under bridges, to beg in the streets, and to steal bread."

Just about the time the British stopped the slave trade, they went into a much bigger business:  selling drugs to the Chinese.   Growing opium in India and shipping it at gunpoint to China was what made the British rich.   And of course there are a lot of Germans in America.   The Anglos and Saxons came to the British Isles from Germany.  English is a Germanic language.
The name Jonathan Pollard seems to ring somewhere in my mind. Refresh me here.
The hanging chad of 2012.

Whether killing Bin Laden was in the interest of the United States, may be uncertain for at least another few centuries. But useful next November,  if Pakistani nukes aren't sneaked into US cities before then.

I am much less concerned about the lack of due process in the killing of bin Laden than I am in the lack of due process for the thousands killed on 9/11 and other al Qaeda attacks.

Attacking civilians without warning and without provocation renders due process moot, in my opinion.

Bill Keller is the venerable elder, polishing the brass, turning the achievements of his watch into a reverie of instructive dreams, telling tales from back-in-the-day. The trouble is the cautionary tales rarely address the progress and evolving needs of the new way. In this case, how the outcry of politics over secrecy has little to do with the issues being puffed up and touted as failures.

Philosopher meet empricist. Secrecy has returned as a tactical strength in operational policy. It helped established BP $20 billion escrow. It has lowered the rhetoric of international hosility. It enabled drone atttacks to be successful and its best example is the termination of bin Laden, achieved not only without a leak, but with feints and actions that utterly concealed a mission unfolding in full force.

To counter these successes, successes in which secrecy worked the way it should, to enhance national security (althrough the death of bin Laden without due process remains worrisome for many), Republicans have raised a frontal attack to obscure and question this success. Call it swift boating secrecy.

But empirically, on the ground, little will change. Breaching secrets has important uses (many cited here!), as many as secrecy does. The key is to realize they are not diametrically opposed to each other, or mutually exclusive. One will not crowd out the other. Both leaks and secrets are safe. But we are thankful for the review.

Republicans should be ashamed of themselves with this shameful idea that they have some god-given right to suppress the votes of the citizenry. They don't. A Pox on them for their biased politics in the United States. The rest of the world is watching them.
Thank you, for making the rest of us aware of this.

Yes. it is. As to responsibility and duty, we have already served. As always, this is one of those double-paybacks like playing the lottery, a scheme where the Republican state makes money from requiring more than was asked by our Constitution. The punishment for this will probably be more than you imagine.
